docs.snippet: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 5 The Brazilian Government informed the United States Embassy today that it would not accept an expected $50 million in military sales credits for the fiscal year beginning October 1978.
docs.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 5 The Brazilian Government informed the United States Embassy today that it would not accept an expected $50 million in military sales credits for the fiscal year beginning October 1978.

headline.main: Brazilian Government Rejects U.S. Military Sales Credits for 1978-79 Period Over the Human Rights Issue

byline.original: By JONATHAN KANDELL Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON In a sense, President Carter's espousal of human rights reflects a peculiarly Western concern. In most parts of the world, outside North America and Western Europe, there is no tradition of political freedom. Moreover, modern technology...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON In a sense, President Carter's espousal of human rights reflects a peculiarly Western concern. In most parts of the world, outside North America and Western Europe, there is no tradition of political freedom. Moreover, modern technology has given autocrats an unparalleled ability to direct, control and discipline their people.

headline.main: Human Rights: The Rest of the World Sees Them Differently

docs.snippet: The jet was delayed at Kennedy Airport for six hours. The travel agent who had secured our cut-rate fares on Argentine Airlines ($636) apologized. "There has been a problem. You have read the papers?" He smiled helplessly.
docs.lead_paragraph: The jet was delayed at Kennedy Airport for six hours. The travel agent who had secured our cut-rate fares on Argentine Airlines ($636) apologized. "There has been a problem. You have read the papers?" He smiled helplessly.

headline.main: Buenos Aires: Is It Safe?; Gratuitous criminal violence is rare, says the author; the problem is political, and the tourist is not apt to be affected. Buenos Aires: Afternoon Tea, Soccer Madness and the Tango

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, March 7 The Carter Administration is drafting a comprehensive new policy for restraining United States arms sales around the world and, it is hoped, sales by other international suppliers of weapons.

docs.abstract: Article on Pres Carter's new policy for restraining US arms sales abroad; pro and con arguments and outlook discussed (L)

docs.snippet: GENEVA, March 8 Brady Tyson of the United States delegation to the United Nations Human Rights Commission expressed "profoundest regrets" today for the part he said some American officials and private groups had played in subverting the Chilean...
docs.lead_paragraph: GENEVA, March 8 Brady Tyson of the United States delegation to the United Nations Human Rights Commission expressed "profoundest regrets" today for the part he said some American officials and private groups had played in subverting the Chilean Government of the late President Salvador Allende Gossens.

headline.main: U.S. Official Expresses 'Regrets' For Role in Chile but Is Disavowed; U.S. AIDE EXPRESSES 'REGRETS' ON CHILE

docs.snippet: GENEVA, March 8 A number of diplomats said here today that the credibility of United States foreign policy has been damaged by the statement yesterday by Brady Tyson expressing "profoundest regrets" for the part he said American officials and private...
docs.lead_paragraph: GENEVA, March 8 A number of diplomats said here today that the credibility of United States foreign policy has been damaged by the statement yesterday by Brady Tyson expressing "profoundest regrets" for the part he said American officials and private groups had played in the subversion of the Allende Government.
docs.abstract: diplomats contend credibility of US foreign policy was damaged by Tyson statement; resolution condemning Chile's mil regime is adopted, 26-1 with 5 abstentions, UN Human Rights Comm meeting, Geneva (S)

docs.snippet: BRASILIA, March 11 Brazil canceled its 25-year-old military assistance treaty with the United States today over a State Department report criticizing its human rights practices.
docs.lead_paragraph: BRASILIA, March 11 Brazil canceled its 25-year-old military assistance treaty with the United States today over a State Department report criticizing its human rights practices.
docs.abstract: Brazil cancels 25-yr-old mil assistance treaty with US on Mar 11 over State Dept rept criticizing its human rights practices; Brazilian Foreign Min says rept constitutes intolerable interference in its internal affairs; document was drawn up under '76 law, which requires human rights repts on all nations scheduled for mil aid; UPI repts Guy Brandao, Brazilian Foreign Min spokesman, says cancellation does not mean Brazil is no longer ally of US; Brazilian reaction linked in part to Carter Adm's drive to upset proposed purchase by Brazil of nuclear reprocessing facilities from West Ger (S)

headline.main: Brazil Cancels Military Aid Treaty Over U.S. Report on Human Rights; Brazil Cancels Military Aid Pact

docs.snippet: BRASILIA, March 11 Brazil canceled its 25-year-old military assistance treaty with the United States today over a State Department report criticizing its human rights practices.
docs.lead_paragraph: BRASILIA, March 11 Brazil canceled its 25-year-old military assistance treaty with the United States today over a State Department report criticizing its human rights practices.
docs.abstract: State Dept silent; spokesman Frederick Z Brawn only confirms that Brazil's Foreign Min notified US Amb John Hugh Crimmins of termination (S)

headline.main: Brazil Cancels Military Aid Treaty Over U.S. Report on Human Rights; Brazil Cancels Military Aid Pact
